title: Paper: Midwifery FQE March 2022
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Community Health Nursing (Midwifery) - March 2022

questions.question: Pregnancy test checks for the presence of:
questions.explanation: Pregnancy tests detect the presence of Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) in urine or blood, which is produced by the placenta shortly after implantation.
questions.hint: The hormone produced by the trophoblast.

questions.question: In early developmental stages, the trophoblast becomes the:
questions.explanation: The blastocyst differentiates into the inner cell mass (embryo) and the outer trophoblast, which develops into the placenta and chorion.

questions.question: Select the four temporary structures in fetal circulation.
questions.explanation: The four temporary structures are: Ductus Venosus, Foramen Ovale, Ductus Arteriosus, and Hypogastric (Umbilical) Arteries.
questions.hint: Shunts and arteries that close after birth.

questions.question: The three bones fused together to make the innominate bones are the:
questions.explanation: Each innominate bone is formed by the fusion of the Ilium, Ischium, and Pubis.
questions.hint: The three parts of the hip bone.

questions.question: The measurements of a non-gravid uterus are approximately:
questions.explanation: Standard dimensions: Length 7.5cm, Width 5cm, Thickness 2.5cm.

questions.question: After 36 weeks of gestation, the lie of the fetus in the uterus is termed as normal if it is:
questions.explanation: Longitudinal lie is the only normal lie for delivery. Vertex is a presentation.

questions.question: Physiological changes that take place in the uterus during first stage of labour include:

options.text: Braxton hicks contractions, effacement, rupture of membranes
Lightening, contraction and retraction of the uterine muscles, increased leucorrhoea
Contraction and retraction of the uterine muscles, effacement, rupture of membranes
Rupture of membranes, show, Braxton hicks contraction

questions.explanation: Key events: Contraction, Retraction (shortening), Effacement, and often Rupture of Membranes.
questions.hint: The muscles work to open the cervix.

questions.question: Select the premonitory signs of labour. (Select correct group)
questions.explanation: Premonitory signs occur before true labor: Lightening, urinary frequency, nesting, weight loss.
questions.hint: Signs that labor is coming soon, not started yet.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding physiological changes in pregnancy are TRUE? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Plasma volume increases by 45–50% reaching peak at 32-34 weeks
Cardiac output increases by 30–50% reaching peak during second trimester

questions.explanation: Both plasma volume and cardiac output increase significantly to support the pregnancy.
questions.hint: The heart works harder and there is more fluid.

questions.question: Minor complications of pregnancy that can occur during the first trimester include:
questions.explanation: Nausea and vomiting are classic 1st trimester complaints. APH is 3rd trimester.

questions.question: Antepartum haemorrhage due to placenta praevia is characterized by:

options.text: Abdomen soft, visible per vaginal bleeding
Abdomen woody hard, visible per vaginal bleeding
Shock corresponds to blood loss, bleeding absent
Abdomen woody hard, shock out of proportion

questions.explanation: Placenta Praevia: Painless, recurrent bright red bleeding, soft uterus. Abruptio: Painful, woody hard uterus.

questions.question: The characteristics of monozygotic twins include:

options.text: Fertilization involved one ova and one sperm, are of same sex
May or may not be of the same sex
Are from two ova and two sperms

questions.explanation: Monozygotic twins come from one zygote and are genetically identical (same sex).

questions.question: During second stage of labour, blood pressure of a mother at risk should be checked every:
questions.explanation: Frequent monitoring (every 15 mins) is required during the active pushing stage for at-risk mothers.

questions.question: The duration of involution of the uterus is the first:
questions.explanation: Involution is complete by the end of the puerperium (6 weeks).

questions.question: Complete rupture of the uterus whereby the fetus escapes the uterine cavity involves which layers?
questions.explanation: Complete rupture involves the full thickness of the uterine wall: Endometrium, Myometrium, and Perimetrium.

questions.question: The hormones responsible for fetal growth and development to maturity include:
questions.explanation: Estrogen promotes growth; Progesterone maintains the pregnancy environment.

questions.question: A mother with cardiac disease grade four presents with:

options.text: Exhaustion even at rest, requiring total nursing care

questions.explanation: NYHA Grade IV indicates symptoms of heart failure even at rest.

questions.question: Cardinal signs for a mother with severe pre-eclampsia include:

options.text: Severe frontal headache, generalised oedema, BP >160/110mmhg

questions.explanation: Severe pre-eclampsia: BP >160/110, proteinuria, cerebral signs (headache).
questions.hint: Very high BP and head pain.

questions.question: The three main causes of post partum haemorrhage are:
questions.explanation: The '4 Ts': Tone (Atony), Trauma (Tears), Tissue (Retained), Thrombin (Coagulopathy). Option A lists three categories.

questions.question: The cases in which vacuum delivery can be conducted during second stage of labour include:

options.text: Fetal distress, maternal distress, cord prolapse
CPD, delivery of a premature baby

questions.explanation: Indications: Fetal distress (to expedite), Maternal exhaustion/distress. Contraindications: CPD, Preterm.

questions.question: The presenting signs and symptoms of antepartum haemorrhage suggestive of placenta abruption include:
questions.explanation: Abruption presents with abdominal pain, uterine tenderness ('woody hard'), and often shock disproportionate to bleeding.

questions.question: Predisposing factors to rupture of the uterus include:
questions.explanation: Obstructed labor (due to CPD, macrosomia) is a major cause of rupture.
questions.hint: When the baby can't pass but the uterus keeps pushing.

questions.question: In Bishop system of cervical scoring an effacement score of three (3) is given when the effacement percentage is:
questions.explanation: A score of 3 is the maximum for effacement, typically assigned for >80% effacement.

questions.question: The schedule of targeted postnatal care visits in health promotion are recommended as follows:

options.text: Within 24 hours, 4-8 hours to one week
Within 48 hours, 1-2 weeks, 4 to 6 weeks, 6 to 12 months

questions.explanation: Standard schedule: 48hrs, 1-2 weeks, 6 weeks, 6 months.

questions.question: Predisposing factors to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) during the postnatal period include:
questions.explanation: Triggers for DIC include Abruption, IUFD, Severe Pre-eclampsia/Eclampsia, and Amniotic Fluid Embolism.
questions.hint: Conditions causing massive tissue factor release.

questions.question: One of the following should be put into consideration when deciding to start Kangaroo-mother care:

options.text: The mother’s willingness to do it

questions.explanation: KMC success depends heavily on the mother's acceptance and willingness to maintain skin-to-skin contact.

questions.question: During pregnancy, the size of the uterus increases to approximately:
questions.explanation: At term, the uterus measures approx 30x23x20 cm.
questions.hint: From a pear to a watermelon.

questions.question: During second stage of labour, a midwife would expect the following signs:

options.text: The vulva and anus gapes, mother has urge to bear down

questions.explanation: Positive/Probable signs of 2nd stage: Expulsive contractions, gaping of anus/vulva, visible presenting part.
questions.hint: The body opens up for delivery.

questions.question: The progression of breast complications in early postpartum period is typically:

options.text: Sore nipples -> cracked nipples -> mastitis -> breast abscess

questions.explanation: Trauma (soreness) leads to cracks, which allow bacteria entry (mastitis), which if untreated forms an abscess.
questions.hint: Damage leads to infection leads to abscess.

questions.question: The sequential flow of lochia loss during the postnatal period is:
questions.explanation: Red (Rubra) -> Pink/Brown (Serosa) -> White (Alba).

questions.question: Cardinal characteristic of per vaginal discharge postnatally to diagnose puerperal sepsis is:
questions.explanation: Offensive (foul-smelling) purulent lochia is the hallmark of puerperal sepsis.

questions.question: The preventive measures of asphyxia neonatorum include:

options.text: Early diagnosis and treatment of obstetrical conditions, proper management of labour

questions.explanation: Proper intrapartum management (monitoring fetal heart rate, partograph) prevents asphyxia.

questions.question: Measures taken to prevent puerperal psychosis include:

options.text: Early diagnosis/counselling of social issues, prompt treatment of blues/depression

questions.explanation: Addressing mental health issues early prevents escalation.

questions.question: Contra-indications of induction of labour include:
questions.explanation: Induction is unsafe if vaginal delivery is impossible (CPD, Previa) or dangerous (Cord prolapse).
questions.hint: Reasons you MUST do a C-section.

questions.question: Characteristics associated with false labour contractions:
questions.explanation: False labor stops or weakens with walking/activity.

questions.question: The causative organism for opthalmia neonatorum is:
questions.explanation: Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis are the primary causes.

questions.question: If the anterior fontanelle is located at the anterior part of the maternal pelvis at the left side, the position is:
questions.explanation: If the Anterior Fontanelle is Left Anterior, the Occiput is Right Posterior (ROP). Note: Options may vary in original text, but this is the anatomical deduction.

questions.question: The presenting diameter in brow presentation is:
questions.explanation: Mento-vertical (13.5 cm) is the largest diameter and presents in brow presentation.

questions.question: The midwives' immediate action once the placenta and membranes are delivered is to:

options.text: Massage the uterus, expel the clots

questions.explanation: Ensuring the uterus is contracted by massaging is the priority to prevent PPH.

questions.question: Draw a well labeled diagram of a non-pregnant uterus illustrating the measurements.
questions.explanation: Labels should include: Fundus, Body, Cervix. Measurements: Length 7.5cm, Width 5cm, Depth 2.5cm.

questions.question: State five (5) benefits of breastfeeding to the mother. (Select 5)
questions.explanation: Benefits include involution, reduced bleeding, contraception, weight loss, and cancer protection.

questions.question: Explain five (5) causes of asphyxia neonatorum. (Select 5)
questions.explanation: Causes usually involve interruption of blood flow (cord/placenta) or poor maternal perfusion.
questions.hint: Things that stop oxygen getting to the baby.

questions.question: Identify physiological changes prenatally in the Cardiovascular, Renal, and Skin systems. (Select correct options)

options.text: CVS: Increased blood volume and cardiac output

questions.explanation: Pregnancy increases blood volume/output, increases kidney filtration, and causes skin pigmentation.
questions.hint: More blood, more urine, darker skin.

questions.question: Outline four (4) objectives of post-natal home visits. (Select 4)
questions.explanation: Objectives are assessment, education, and early detection of problems.
questions.hint: Check mom and baby, teach them.

questions.question: Explain the evaluation scale which is done on neonates one minute after birth.
questions.explanation: The APGAR score assesses Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, and Respiration.

questions.question: Explain three (3) elements in Bishop’s score leading to successful Induction of labour. (Select 3)
questions.explanation: Bishop score assesses Cervix (Dilation, Effacement, Consistency, Position) and Station.

questions.question: Explain two (2) pillars of safe motherhood. (Select 2)
questions.explanation: Pillars: FP, ANC, Safe Delivery, EOC, PNC.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for management of neonatal jaundice (Baby Kim) receiving phototherapy:

items.text: Place under lights at correct distance

questions.explanation: Key steps: Protection, Exposure, Hydration, Monitoring.
questions.hint: Protect eyes first, then expose skin.
